comments:
This course is intended to introduce students to the field of engineering. Students will be exposed to the engineering disciplines through hands-on laboratory experiences, tutorials on how to use important software packages, and a "Professional Preparation" module that incorporates studies of communication (writing and speaking skills), ethics, leadership and teamwork.

Students who took this course have reported that it helped them “explore different majors within engineering” but emphasized that the class “only scratches the surface of each field.” One student commented, “I learned how to work with other engineers in teams to complete group reports.” Students also noted that although the lab portion of this course was not particularly stimulating, “the evening lectures and alumni interviews were helpful” in determining which academic pathway to take within engineering. 

Most students considered Professor Pope to be a harsh grader and many criticized the lack of communication between students, TAs and the professor.

This course was described by those who took it as “extremely challenging” due to its many “tedious” lab reports. EAS 101 is ideal for any freshman interested in exploring the possibility of studying engineering at Penn, and counts as an engineering requirement in SEAS.
